sanskrit:
काश्यश्च परमेष्वासः शिखण्डी च महारथः |
धृष्टद्युम्नो विराटश्च सात्यकिश्चापराजितः ||१७||
transliteration:
kāśyaś ca parameṣvāsaḥ śikhaṇḍī ca mahārathaḥ |
dhṛṣṭadyumno virāṭaś ca sātyakiś cāparājitaḥ ||17||
translation: The King of Kashi, a supreme archer; Shikhandi, a mighty warrior; Dhrishtadyumna and Virata, and the invincible Satyaki.
commentary:
In this verse, Sanjaya continues his enumeration of the prominent warriors assembled on the Pandava side. He names five distinguished heroes, each renowned for their martial prowess. The King of Kashi (Kashiraja) is praised as a 'parameṣvāsa' (supreme archer), indicating his exceptional skill with the bow. Shikhandi holds particular significance in the Mahabharata narrative as the warrior destined to be instrumental in Bhishma's fall. Dhrishtadyumna, born from fire, is the brother of Draupadi and commander of the Pandava forces, who would eventually slay Drona. Virata, the king who sheltered the Pandavas during their year of hiding in disguise, represents loyalty and hospitality rewarded.

Satyaki, described as 'aparājita' (unconquered or invincible), was a Yadava warrior and devoted student of Arjuna, representing the personal connection between Krishna's clan and the Pandavas. This systematic cataloging of warriors serves multiple purposes: it demonstrates the formidable strength of both armies, builds dramatic tension before the great battle, and establishes the magnitude of the impending conflict. The verse emphasizes that the Pandava army is not merely numerous but consists of exceptional warriors, each a 'maharatha' (great chariot warrior) in their own right, capable of facing thousands of ordinary soldiers. This enumeration sets the stage for Arjuna's subsequent moral crisis, as he contemplates the destruction of such noble warriors.
speaker: Sanjaya
